Bounded sesquilinear forms {#bounded-sesquilinear-forms .unnumbered}
==========================

Let $H_1$, $H_2$ be two Hilbert spaces.

[**Definition -**]{} A sesquilinear form
$[\cdot, \cdot ] : H_1 \times H_2 \to \mathbb{C}$ is said to be
*bounded* if there is a constant $C \geq 0$ such that

$$\begin{aligned}
[\xi, \eta ] \leq C \| \xi \| \| \eta \|\end{aligned}$$

for all $\xi \in H_1$ and $\eta \in H_2$.

Bounded sesquilinear forms are precisely those which are continuous from
$H_1 \times H_2$ to $\mathbb{C}$.

[**Examples :**]{}

-   When $H_1$ and $H_2$ are the same Hilbert space, denoted by $H$, the
    inner product $\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle$ in $H$ is itself a
    bounded sesquilinear form. The boundedness condition follows from
    the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality.

-   Let $T: H_1 \to H_2$ be a bounded linear operator and denote by
    $\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle$ the inner product in $H_2$. The
    function $[\cdot, \cdot ] : H_1 \times H_2 \to \mathbb{C}$ defined
    by $$\begin{aligned}
    [\xi, \eta ] := \langle T \xi, \eta \rangle\end{aligned}$$ is a
    bounded sesquilinear form. The boundedness condition follows from
    the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and the fact that $T$ is bounded.

Riesz representation of bounded sesquilinear forms {#riesz-representation-of-bounded-sesquilinear-forms .unnumbered}
==================================================

The second example above is in fact the general case. To every bounded
sesquilinear form one can associate to it a unique bounded operator.
That is content of the following result:

[**Theorem - Riesz -**]{} Let $H_1$, $H_2$ be two Hilbert spaces and
denote by $\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle$ the inner product in $H_2$. For
every bounded sesquilinear form
$[\cdot, \cdot]: H_1 \times H_2 \to \mathbb{C}$ there is a unique
bounded linear operator $T: H_1 \to H_2$ such that

$$\begin{aligned}
[\xi, \eta ] = \langle T \xi , \eta \rangle\,, \qquad\qquad \xi \in H_1, \eta \in H_2.\end{aligned}$$

Thus, there is a correspondence between bounded linear operators and
bounded sesquilinear forms. Actually, in the early twentieth century,
spectral theory was formulated solely in terms of sesquilinear forms on
Hilbert spaces. Only later it was realized that this could be achieved,
perhaps in a more intuitive manner, by considering linear operators
instead. The linear operator approach has its advantages, as for example
one can define the composition of linear operators but not of
sesquilinear forms. Nevertheless it is many times useful to define a
linear operator by specifying its sesquilinear form.
